title: International Business Comprehensive Test Bank
description: Expanded 150-question objective test aligned with 2025-2026 FBLA competitive event guidelines for International Business.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the 'glocalization' strategy in international business?
options: Standardizing all products to maintain a consistent global brand identity
Adjusting global products to meet the specific needs of local consumers
Focusing exclusively on domestic production while exporting all surpluses
Removing all international branches to focus on one primary home market

questions.text: The Heckscher-Ohlin theory of international trade primarily focuses on which factor?
options: The relative abundance of labor and capital within a specific nation
The historical dominance of colonial powers in modern trade networks
The total value of gold and silver reserves held by a central government
The technological innovation cycles found in highly developed economies

questions.text: What is a primary characteristic of a 'greenfield' investment in a foreign market?
options: Purchasing an existing firm to gain immediate access to local customers
Establishing a brand-new facility from the ground up in another country
Partnering with a local government to manage public utility infrastructures
Acquiring only the intellectual property rights of a struggling competitor

questions.text: A 'turnkey' project in international business is best defined as a contract where:
options: A firm handles every detail of a project for a foreign client upon completion
A company leases its manufacturing equipment to a local startup enterprise
A business sells its voting stock to a group of international private equity firms
A manager is hired to oversee a foreign branch for a limited six-month period

questions.text: Which legal system is based on a very detailed set of written laws and organized codes?
options: Common law system
Theocratic law system
Civil law system
Customary law system

questions.text: In a 'high-context' culture, communication is most likely to be characterized by:
options: A heavy reliance on explicit verbal instructions and written documentation
The use of non-verbal cues and the social standing of the participants
A preference for direct confrontation when resolving professional disputes
The complete separation of personal relationships from business dealings

questions.text: Ethnocentrism in a global business environment is best described as the belief that:
options: All cultures are equally valid and should be respected in every market
One's own culture is inherently superior to the cultures of other nations
International business should only be conducted in a single global language
Diverse cultural backgrounds are the primary source of corporate innovation

questions.text: Which element of the marketing mix is most affected by 'gray market' activities?
options: Product development
Pricing strategies
Promotion campaigns
Personnel training

questions.text: A 'push strategy' in international marketing primarily emphasizes the use of:
options: Mass media advertising to build direct consumer demand for a product
A personal sales force and trade promotions to move goods through channels
Social media influencers to create viral awareness among younger buyers
Public relations campaigns to improve the general image of the corporation

questions.text: The 'current account' section of a nation's balance of payments includes:
options: The net changes in the ownership of national assets and foreign stocks
The value of all exports and imports of goods, services, and income
The total amount of gold reserves currently held by the central bank
The long-term loans provided by the World Bank for infrastructure projects

questions.text: A 'spot exchange rate' is the rate at which a foreign exchange dealer converts:
options: Currency on a specific date in the future using a pre-set contractual value
Currency at that particular moment for immediate delivery and settlement
Currency only between two central banks during an economic crisis event
Currency for large multinational corporations at a significant discount

questions.text: A 'polycentric' staffing policy in a multinational corporation focuses on:
options: Hiring only citizens from the home country for all top management positions
Recruiting host-country nationals to manage subsidiaries in their own land
Seeking the best people for key jobs throughout the firm regardless of nationality
Rotating all employees through different global offices every two years

questions.text: The 'Foreign Corrupt Practices Act' (FCPA) primarily prohibits U.S. companies from:
options: Hiring foreign workers at wages lower than the U.S. federal minimum wage
Paying bribes to foreign government officials to obtain or retain business
Selling products in countries that have high levels of political instability
Exporting sensitive technology to nations that are not members of the WTO

questions.text: The primary goal of the North American Free Trade Agreement (superseded by USMCA) was:
options: The creation of a common currency to be used across the entire continent
The elimination of most tariffs on trade between the three member nations
The establishment of a unified military force to protect regional borders
The migration of all manufacturing jobs to a single centralized location

questions.text: An 'ad valorem' tariff is a tax that is calculated as a percentage of the:
options: Physical weight of the imported goods regardless of their market value
Total assessed value of the imported goods coming into the country
Profit margins expected by the domestic company selling the imports
Average price of similar goods produced by local manufacturing firms

questions.text: Mercantilism is an economic philosophy that suggests nations should:
options: Encourage imports from all countries to lower prices for local citizens
Maintain a trade surplus by exporting more than they choose to import
Focus entirely on service industries rather than physical manufacturing
Abolish all forms of government intervention in the international market

questions.text: In a 'franchising' agreement, the franchisor typically provides the franchisee with:
options: Complete ownership of the parent corporation's stock and global assets
A brand name, operating systems, and ongoing support for a royalty fee
Free raw materials and labor for the first five years of the business operation
Legal immunity from all local taxes and national environmental regulations

questions.text: A 'patent' provides an inventor with exclusive rights for a defined period to:
options: The use of a specific artistic work like a song, book, or movie script
The manufacture, use, or sale of a specific new and useful invention
The unique logo or symbol that identifies a company in the marketplace
The secret recipe used in a food product that remains unpatented

questions.text: The term 'proxemics' refers to the study of how people in different cultures use:
options: Time management and scheduling in a professional business environment
Physical space and distance during social and professional interactions
Pitch and tone of voice to convey meaning beyond the literal words said
Formal titles and honorifics when addressing senior executive leadership

questions.text: When a firm uses 'price skimming,' it sets the initial price of a new product:
options: At the lowest possible level to gain market share as quickly as possible
At a high level to capture value from customers willing to pay a premium
Equal to the prices charged by all other competitors currently in the market
Based solely on the cost of production plus a very small fixed percentage

questions.text: A 'Eurobond' is a bond that is issued by a company or government and is:
options: Denominated in a currency other than that of the country where it is issued
Only available for purchase by citizens of the European Union member states
Backed by the physical gold reserves held by the European Central Bank
Required to be paid back in the local currency of the issuing corporation

questions.text: The 'Big Mac Index' is an informal way of measuring which economic concept?
options: The total health of the global fast food industry in developing nations
Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) between different national currencies
The rate of obesity-related healthcare costs in industrialized countries
The percentage of disposable income spent on dining out worldwide

questions.text: An 'expatriate manager' is a professional who is currently working in:
options: The home country office of a company they have worked for many years
A country other than his or her native country for a business entity
A non-profit organization that focuses on global environmental protection
A government agency that regulates international trade and tax policies

questions.text: The 'Sullivan Principles' were originally developed to guide companies doing business in:
options: Communist China during the height of the Cold War era in the 1960s
South Africa during the period of racial segregation known as apartheid
The Soviet Union after the fall of the Berlin Wall in the early 1990s
South America during the era of high inflation and political dictatorships

questions.text: The 'Most Favored Nation' (MFN) status in the WTO framework ensures that:
options: A country can choose its favorite trade partner and ignore all others
Any trade concession given to one member must be given to all members
Developing nations are exempted from all environmental protection laws
Agricultural goods are taxed at a higher rate than manufactured products

questions.text: A 'voluntary export restraint' (VER) is a trade restriction that is:
options: Imposed by the importing country to limit the quantity of foreign goods
Set by the exporting country, often at the request of the importer
Mandated by the World Trade Organization for all its member nations
Applied only to high-tech products that have potential military uses

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of an 'invisible' export in international trade?
options: The shipment of raw iron ore to a steel mill in a foreign country
Banking and consulting services provided to an international client
The sale of luxury automobiles manufactured in a domestic factory
The delivery of agricultural grain to a nation facing a food shortage

questions.text: A 'joint venture' is a type of international business arrangement where:
options: One company buys out all the assets of another firm to eliminate it
Two or more firms share ownership of a new enterprise for a project
A government takes over the operations of a private foreign subsidiary
A single entrepreneur starts a business using only their personal savings

questions.text: The 'CISG' (Contracts for the International Sale of Goods) is a treaty that:
options: Regulates the minimum wage for workers in the global textile industry
Provides a uniform framework for international commercial contracts
Limits the amount of carbon emissions produced by global shipping fleets
Prevents companies from owning more than 50% of a foreign subsidiary

questions.text: In 'monochronic' cultures, people tend to view time as something that:
options: Is fluid and allows for many different tasks to be handled at once
Is linear and should be divided into small, strictly scheduled blocks
Does not influence the outcome of a business meeting or negotiation
Is secondary to the importance of building deep personal relationships

questions.text: The 'international product life cycle' theory suggests that new products are first:
options: Developed and produced in the country with the lowest labor costs
Produced in the home country and then exported to other developed nations
Manufactured in developing countries and sold back to the United States
Created by international organizations like the United Nations for all

questions.text: A 'letter of credit' is a document issued by a bank that guarantees:
options: That a company's stock price will not fall below a certain level this year
Payment to a seller once specific shipping documents are presented
The safe arrival of goods at a foreign port without any physical damage
That the government of the importing country will not raise its tariffs

questions.text: What happens to a currency when it 'depreciates' in a floating exchange rate system?
options: The government officially sets a new, higher value for the currency
The value of the currency decreases relative to other foreign currencies
The currency is replaced by a new system based on a basket of goods
The central bank increases interest rates to attract foreign investment

questions.text: The 'balance sheet approach' to expatriate compensation aims to ensure that:
options: The manager earns exactly the same salary as the local workers in the host country
The manager maintains the same standard of living as they had in their home country
The company pays no taxes to the host country for the duration of the assignment
The expatriate receives all of their pay in the form of company stock options

questions.text: The 'tragedy of the commons' occurs in international business when:
options: A company refuses to share its technological secrets with its competitors
A resource held in common by all is overexploited by individuals for profit
Global trade barriers are removed and local small businesses go bankrupt
A government nationalizes all foreign assets without providing compensation

questions.text: A 'customs union' is a level of economic integration that includes a free trade area and:
options: A common currency used by all the member nations of the union
A common external trade policy toward non-member countries
The free movement of labor and capital across the internal borders
A unified political system with a single central government for all

questions.text: A 'local content requirement' is a regulation that demands that some fraction of a product:
options: Be sold only to local citizens at a price set by the government
Be produced domestically using local inputs and local labor
Be recycled in the same country where it was originally manufactured
Be labeled in the local language with a list of all raw ingredients

questions.text: The 'Leontief Paradox' challenged which of the following trade theories?
options: Comparative advantage
Heckscher-Ohlin theory
Product life cycle theory
Mercantilism theory

questions.text: A 'wholly owned subsidiary' is an entry mode where the parent firm owns:
options: Less than 10% of the voting stock in the foreign company
Exactly 50% of the equity in a partnership with a local firm
100% of the stock in the business operation in the foreign market
Only the physical building but not the brand name or equipment

questions.text: In the United States, intellectual property theft is primarily prosecuted under:
options: The Sherman Antitrust Act
The Economic Espionage Act
The Glass-Steagall Act
The Sarbanes-Oxley Act

questions.text: What does the term 'lingua franca' refer to in a global business context?
options: A type of currency used only in the French-speaking regions of Africa
A common language used for communication between people of different tongues
A formal set of rules for writing international legal contracts and treaties
The cultural practice of giving gifts during a first business negotiation

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of 'market segmentation' in international trade?
options: Selling the exact same product to every person in the world at one price
Dividing a global market into groups of consumers with similar needs
Removing a product from a market because it is no longer profitable
Focusing all marketing efforts on the home country's wealthy elite

questions.text: The 'International Monetary Fund' (IMF) was primarily established to:
options: Provide long-term loans for the construction of dams and bridges
Maintain order in the international monetary system and help countries in crisis
Act as a global central bank that issues a single world currency
Regulate the environmental standards for the global shipping industry

questions.text: A 'managed float' system (also known as a dirty float) is where:
options: The currency value is fixed to a set amount of gold in a vault
Market forces set values but the central bank intervenes occasionally
The government sets the exchange rate and changes it every decade
The exchange rate is determined entirely by the supply of oil

questions.text: Which of the following is a common cause of 'expatriate failure' (premature return)?
options: The manager receives a salary that is too high for the host country
The inability of the manager's spouse or family to adapt to the new culture
The manager becomes too proficient in the local language of the host nation
The company provides too much pre-departure training to the employee

questions.text: The concept of 'Corporate Social Responsibility' (CSR) suggests that firms should:
options: Focus exclusively on maximizing profits for their shareholders
Consider the interests of all stakeholders including the environment
Avoid all international trade to protect domestic jobs and industries
Only follow the laws of their home country regardless of where they operate

questions.text: An 'economic union' is the most integrated form of regional trade because it includes:
options: A free trade area with common external tariffs and a shared currency
The removal of all physical borders between the member nations
A common market, common external tariffs, and harmonized economic policies
The merging of all member countries into a single sovereign superpower

questions.text: A 'subsidy' provided by a government to a domestic producer is intended to:
options: Increase the price of goods sold in the domestic market to help firms
Lower production costs to help the firm compete against foreign imports
Prevent the firm from selling any of its products in the global market
Force the company to hire only workers from a specific political party

questions.text: The 'absolute advantage' theory was first proposed by which economist?
options: David Ricardo
Adam Smith
Michael Porter
John Maynard Keynes

questions.text: What is the primary risk of a 'licensing' agreement for the licensor?
options: The licensor must provide all the capital to build a foreign factory
The licensee might become a future competitor by learning the technology
The licensor is responsible for all local marketing and distribution costs
The government of the host country will likely nationalize the brand

questions.text: The 'arbitration' process in international business disputes is:
options: A public trial held in the capital city of the host country's government
A private method of dispute resolution where a neutral third party decides
A formal protest filed with the United Nations General Assembly
A negotiation where the two parties agree to flip a coin for the outcome

questions.text: The 'silent language' of business often refers to the use of:
options: Secret codes used to encrypt financial data during digital transfers
Non-verbal communication such as gestures, eye contact, and posture
The specific technical jargon used by engineers in the oil industry
Written memos that are circulated within an office but never spoken

questions.text: In 'dumping,' a company sells its products in a foreign market at a price that is:
options: Higher than the price charged in its home market to maximize profit
Below the cost of production or below the fair market value
Exactly equal to the average price of all competing products in that land
Adjusted daily based on the fluctuating value of the local currency

questions.text: The 'World Bank' primarily focuses on providing financial assistance for:
options: Short-term currency stabilization in developed Western economies
Economic development and poverty reduction in developing nations
The management of the global stock market and private equity firms
The enforcement of intellectual property rights in the technology sector

questions.text: A 'forward exchange' occurs when two parties agree to exchange currency:
options: Immediately at the current market rate provided by the local bank
At a specific future date using a rate that is agreed upon today
Only if the value of the currency drops by more than ten percent
Using a physical exchange of gold bars instead of digital money

questions.text: An 'ethnocentric' staffing policy is most often used when a firm:
options: Wants to adapt its products as much as possible to the local culture
Wants to maintain a strong corporate culture and transfer core skills
Operates in a country that has a very high level of technical expertise
Is trying to reduce the high cost of relocating managers from overseas

questions.text: Which ethical viewpoint argues that 'when in Rome, do as the Romans do'?
options: Cultural Relativism
Righteous Moralist
Naïve Immoralist
Utilitarianism

questions.text: The 'European Union' (EU) is an example of which level of economic integration?
options: Free Trade Area
Customs Union
Economic Union
Common Market

questions.text: A 'quota' is a direct restriction on the:
options: Price that can be charged for an imported good in the domestic market
Quantity of some good that may be imported into a country
Amount of money a foreigner can invest in a local stock market
Number of days it takes for a ship to be cleared through customs

questions.text: Globalization of 'production' allows companies to:
options: Sell the same product in every country without any modifications
Disperse parts of their productive process to various global locations
Avoid paying any taxes to their home country's central government
Hire only workers from their own hometown to ensure product quality

questions.text: Strategic alliances are cooperative agreements between:
options: Two companies that are both owned by the same parent corporation
Potential or actual competitors to achieve a common business goal
A government and a non-profit organization to provide social aid
A firm and its retired employees to provide ongoing health benefits

questions.text: The 'Righteous Moralist' approach to ethics in international business claims:
options: That local standards of the host country should always be followed
That the home-country standards of ethics should be followed everywhere
That if a competitor is acting unethically, it is okay to do the same
That the action that produces the most good for most people is best

questions.text: A 'collectivist' culture, according to Hofstede, is one in which:
options: Individuals are expected to take care of themselves and their family
People are integrated into strong, cohesive groups from birth onward
The government owns all the means of production and distribution
Wealth is distributed equally among all citizens by the central bank

questions.text: A 'global brand' is one that uses which of the following?
options: Different names and different logos for every country it enters
The same name and a similar image in all of its global markets
No names or logos to avoid offending people in different cultures
Names that are translated literally into every local dialect spoken

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a 'soft currency'?
options: The U.S. Dollar (USD)
The Euro (EUR)
A currency that is difficult to convert into other currencies
The Japanese Yen (JPY)

questions.text: The 'arbitrage' process in currency markets involves:
options: Buying a currency low and selling it high in a different market
Waiting for a government to change its exchange rate policy
Investing in gold when the value of the dollar begins to fall
Hiring a professional to negotiate a better rate with a local bank

questions.text: A 'geocentric' staffing policy is generally considered to be the most:
options: Expensive policy because of the high cost of training all employees
Effective policy for building a truly international management team
Dangerous policy because of the risk of losing corporate secrets
Common policy for small businesses just starting to export goods

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of an 'externality' in global trade?
options: The price of a product sold in a retail store in a foreign country
The pollution created by a factory that affects a nearby community
The salary paid to a manager working in an overseas subsidiary
The tariff paid to a government when importing electronic goods

questions.text: The 'ASEAN' trade bloc is located in which part of the world?
options: South America
Southeast Asia
Eastern Europe
North Africa

questions.text: A 'tax haven' is a country or territory that offers foreign individuals:
options: High levels of social services in exchange for high income taxes
Little or no tax liability in a politically and economically stable environment
A guaranteed job in the government for anyone who invests money
The right to vote in local elections if they buy a piece of real estate

questions.text: What is the 'infant industry argument' used by some governments?
options: The claim that a nation should focus on producing toys for children
The idea that new industries need protection until they are competitive
The belief that only older, established firms should be allowed to export
The suggestion that governments should pay for all daycare for workers

questions.text: A 'multidomestic' strategy involves which of the following?
options: Standardizing all products to reduce costs through economies of scale
Customizing products and marketing to match local conditions
Focusing only on the home market and ignoring all foreign buyers
Merging with a competitor in every single country the firm enters

questions.text: The term 'expropriation' refers to a government action where:
options: A company is given a large tax break to encourage it to stay in the country
Private property is taken by the government for a public purpose with pay
International trade is encouraged by removing all existing tariffs
A firm is forced to sell its products at a price below the cost of production

questions.text: Power Distance, as defined by Geert Hofstede, measures the extent to which:
options: A society uses electricity and other forms of energy in its factories
Less powerful members of a society accept that power is distributed unequally
A country is able to project its military strength into other regions
Individual citizens are able to influence the decisions of the government

questions.text: In international business, 'countertrade' refers to:
options: Trading goods and services for other goods and services instead of money
Setting up a retail store that sells only products from foreign nations
The process of counting all the inventory in a warehouse once a year
A strategy where a firm buys back its own stock to increase the price

questions.text: A 'capital account' in the balance of payments tracks which of the following?
options: The daily sales of consumer goods to foreign tourists in the home country
The movement of financial capital into and out of a specific country
The total amount of tax revenue collected by the national government
The value of agricultural products exported to neighboring nations

questions.text: The 'International Fisher Effect' suggests that for any two countries:
options: The spot exchange rate should change in an equal amount to the inflation rate
The nominal interest rate is the sum of the required real interest rate and inflation
The government should always maintain a fixed exchange rate to ensure stability
The price of a basket of goods should be exactly the same in both nations

questions.text: The 'repatriation' process involves which of the following?
options: Sending a manager to a foreign country for a new three-year assignment
The transition of an expatriate manager back into their home country
Hiring a local person to replace a manager who has just been fired
Paying a manager a bonus for successfully finishing a project on time

questions.text: The 'Naïve Immoralist' ethical perspective argues that:
options: A manager should always follow the highest ethical standards of their home
If a manager sees firms from other nations ignoring ethics, they should too
Ethical decisions should be made based on the local laws of the host nation
The most ethical action is the one that provides the most profit for a firm

questions.text: Which organization replaced the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT)?
options: The World Bank
The World Trade Organization
The International Monetary Fund
The United Nations

questions.text: A 'compound tariff' is a trade tax that consists of both:
options: An income tax and a sales tax applied to the same physical product
A specific tariff and an ad valorem tariff applied to the same product
A local tax and a national tax that are collected by the same agency
A tax on the raw materials and a tax on the finished consumer good

questions.text: The 'Comparative Advantage' theory was developed by which economist?
options: Adam Smith
David Ricardo
Karl Marx
Milton Friedman

questions.text: A 'licensing' agreement is most commonly used in which industry?
options: Mining and raw material extraction
Manufacturing and technology
Professional accounting services
Agricultural farming and harvesting

questions.text: The 'Foreign Corrupt Practices Act' applies to which of the following?
options: Only companies that are headquartered in European Union member states
All U.S. companies and their officers, directors, and employees
Only companies that have more than ten thousand global employees
Only government agencies that are involved in international diplomacy

questions.text: Uncertainty Avoidance, in Hofstede's model, refers to the degree to which:
options: People in a society feel uncomfortable with ambiguity and risk
A government is able to predict the future movements of the stock market
Individuals are willing to travel to foreign countries for their jobs
Businesses are able to avoid paying taxes by using offshore accounts

questions.text: A 'pull strategy' in marketing is best described as one that:
options: Forces wholesalers to stock a product by offering them a large discount
Creates consumer demand through advertising to get retailers to stock it
Uses high-pressure sales tactics to convince a customer to buy now
Relies on the government to mandate that a product be sold in stores

questions.text: The 'London Interbank Offered Rate' (LIBOR) was a benchmark for:
options: The price of gold on the London Stock Exchange every morning
Short-term interest rates at which banks lend to one another
The exchange rate between the British Pound and the U.S. Dollar
The minimum wage for workers in the United Kingdom's service sector

questions.text: A 'currency swap' is an agreement between two parties to:
options: Exchange principal and interest payments in different currencies
Trade their physical paper money for digital currency at a bank
Give all their money to the government in exchange for tax breaks
Wait for the exchange rate to improve before buying any foreign goods

questions.text: An 'inpatriate' is a manager who is transferred from:
options: A foreign subsidiary to work at the headquarters in the home country
The home country headquarters to work at a foreign subsidiary office
A competitor's office to work for the firm in the same local city
A government job to a private sector job in the international market

questions.text: The 'OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises' are intended to:
options: Force all companies to pay the same taxes regardless of their location
Provide non-binding standards for responsible business conduct globally
Limit the amount of profit a company can make in a developing nation
Prohibit companies from using any plastic in their packaging materials

questions.text: The 'Mercosur' trade agreement includes countries from which region?
options: Western Europe
South America
Central Africa
The Middle East

questions.text: A 'specific tariff' is a trade tax that is levied as a:
options: Percentage of the total value of the imported goods coming in
Fixed charge for each unit of a good that is imported into the land
Fee that depends on the income level of the company importing it
Tax that is only applied to goods that are considered to be luxury items

questions.text: The 'Product Life Cycle' theory of trade was developed by:
options: Raymond Vernon
Michael Porter
Adam Smith
David Ricardo

questions.text: Which entry mode provides a firm with the most control over its foreign operations?
options: Exporting
Licensing
Franchising
Wholly Owned Subsidiary

questions.text: The 'TRIPS' agreement in the WTO framework deals with:
options: The safety of global air travel and international flight regulations
The protection of intellectual property rights across member nations
The reduction of tariffs on agricultural goods like wheat and corn
The minimum standards for working conditions in foreign factories

questions.text: The term 'kinesics' is the study of communication through:
options: The use of written language and formal digital correspondence
Body movements, facial expressions, and various physical gestures
The amount of time it takes to respond to an email or a phone call
The specific clothing and jewelry worn by business professionals

questions.text: When a firm uses 'penetration pricing,' it sets the initial price:
options: As high as possible to establish the brand as a luxury status symbol
Low to attract a large number of buyers and a large market share
Exactly equal to the price charged by the most famous global brand
Based on the average price of all the goods sold in that country

questions.text: A 'hard currency' is one that is expected to:
options: Decrease in value very quickly due to high levels of local inflation
Remain stable and be easily traded on the international exchange
Be made only of physical metal coins rather than paper or digital
Only be used within the borders of a single developing nation

questions.text: The 'Law of One Price' states that in competitive markets free of trade barriers:
options: Identical products sold in different countries must sell for the same price
The government must set the price for every product sold in the country
Every consumer must be charged the same price regardless of their income
Prices must be adjusted every hour to match the value of the local currency

questions.text: A 'geocentric' staffing policy is difficult to implement because of:
options: The low cost of local labor making it unnecessary to hire from abroad
Immigration laws and the high cost of relocating many international managers
The lack of people in the world who are willing to work in other countries
The requirement that all managers must speak at least five different languages

questions.text: The 'Utilitarian' approach to business ethics suggests that an action is right if:
options: It follows the strict laws and regulations of the home country government
It leads to the best possible balance of good versus bad consequences
It is what most other successful companies are currently doing in the market
It increases the personal wealth of the managers who made the decision

questions.text: The 'Common Market' level of integration adds what to a customs union?
options: A common currency like the Euro or the U.S. Dollar for all members
The free movement of the factors of production like labor and capital
A unified parliament that makes all the laws for every member nation
The complete removal of all national flags and symbols of identity

questions.text: An 'import license' is a document issued by a government that:
options: Allows a person to travel to a foreign country to buy consumer goods
Grants permission to a firm to bring specific goods into the country
Certifies that a product was made without the use of any child labor
Gives a company the right to sell its products in a foreign stock market

questions.text: Which of the following is a 'driver' of modern globalization?
options: Increasing trade barriers and higher tariffs on electronic imports
Advances in communication and transportation technology worldwide
The return to a gold standard for all major national currencies
A decrease in the number of people who are willing to travel abroad

questions.text: In a 'global standardization' strategy, a firm focuses on:
options: Maximum local responsiveness to meet the needs of every single consumer
Increasing profitability by reaping the cost reductions of scale economies
Operating only in the home country to avoid the risks of global markets
Hiring only local people to manage the offices in every foreign country

questions.text: The 'Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property' deals with:
options: Minimum wage laws for workers in the global manufacturing industry
The international protection of patents and various trademarks
The safety standards for chemicals used in the production of plastics
The amount of tax a company must pay when it builds a new factory

questions.text: A 'low-context' culture is one in which communication is mostly:
options: Based on the personal relationships and family history of the speaker
Explicit and depends on the literal meaning of the words being used
Conveyed through silence and long pauses during a business meeting
Handled by a third party who acts as a translator for both of the groups

questions.text: A 'standardized' global advertising campaign uses:
options: Different images and different messages for every country it enters
The same basic message and same visual creative in all global markets
Only radio ads in developing nations and only TV ads in developed ones
Messages that are written by local people in every single city it serves

questions.text: The 'Gold Standard' was a monetary system in which:
options: Governments only used gold coins for all of their internal purchases
The value of a currency was directly linked to a specific amount of gold
Companies were required to pay their employees in physical gold bars
International trade was only allowed between nations that owned gold mines

questions.text: A 'floating' exchange rate is determined entirely by:
options: The government of the country that issues the specific currency
The supply and demand for the currency in the global foreign market
The total amount of oil that a country is able to export every month
A committee of experts at the International Monetary Fund headquarters

questions.text: The 'ethnocentric' approach is most common among companies that are:
options: Highly international and have many years of experience in foreign lands
Just beginning their international operations and lack global experience
Operating in industries that have very low levels of technical complexity
Headquartered in countries that have very small domestic populations

questions.text: The 'Kantain' ethics perspective argues that people should:
options: Always be treated as ends in themselves and never as mere means to an end
Only follow the laws that are beneficial to their own personal wealth
Act in a way that provides the most happiness for the largest number of people
Follow the traditions of their culture even if those traditions are harmful

questions.text: The 'African Continental Free Trade Area' (AfCFTA) aims to:
options: Create a single currency for all the nations on the African continent
Eliminate tariffs on most goods and services between African nations
Build a high-speed railway that connects every major city in Africa
Prevent any non-African companies from doing business on the continent

questions.text: An 'export subsidy' is a payment by a government to a:
options: Foreign company to encourage them to build a factory in the country
Domestic firm to encourage them to sell their products in foreign lands
Local citizen to help them buy imported luxury goods from other nations
Non-profit organization to provide healthcare services in rural areas

questions.text: The 'New Trade Theory' suggests that trade can increase because of:
options: The absolute differences in the weather and climate between two nations
Economies of scale and the first-mover advantages in certain industries
The total number of people who live in a country regardless of their skills
The historical use of gold as the primary medium of exchange worldwide

questions.text: A 'transnational' strategy seeks to achieve which two goals simultaneously?
options: Low cost and high local responsiveness in every market the firm enters
High prices and a very small market share in developing global nations
No local adaptation and no concern for the cost of the manufacturing
Total government ownership and complete private control of the assets

questions.text: A 'trademark' is a legally protected design, name, or symbol that:
options: Describes the chemical ingredients that are used in a pharmaceutical drug
Identifies the source of a product and distinguishes it from competitors
Prevents other people from reading a book without paying for a copy
Allows a person to travel across international borders without a visa

questions.text: In Hofstede's model, 'Masculinity' refers to a society that values:
options: Cooperation, modesty, caring for the weak, and the general quality of life
Achievement, heroism, assertiveness, and material rewards for success
The equal distribution of wealth between all the citizens of the nation
The protection of the environment over the growth of the local economy

questions.text: Which of the following is a barrier to using a 'standardized' global marketing mix?
options: The increasing use of the internet to buy products from other countries
Cultural differences and varying government regulations in each nation
The fact that most people in the world now speak the same language
The decrease in the cost of shipping goods across the various oceans

questions.text: A 'foreign bond' is a bond that is issued by a foreign entity but is:
options: Denominated in the currency of the country where it is being sold
Only sold to people who have a dual citizenship in both of the nations
Backed by the government of the country where the company is located
Required to be paid back in physical gold bars instead of digital money

questions.text: The 'Bretton Woods' agreement established which of the following systems?
options: A floating exchange rate system where market forces set all values
A fixed exchange rate system where currencies were pegged to the dollar
A system where only gold could be used for any international trade
A global tax on all currency exchanges to fund the United Nations

questions.text: The 'polycentric' approach to staffing can lead to which of the following problems?
options: A lack of local knowledge in the foreign offices of the corporation
A gap between the home office and the foreign subsidiaries of the firm
The high cost of moving many managers from the home country to abroad
The inability to find any local people who are willing to work for the firm

questions.text: The 'Justice Theory' of ethics focuses on which of the following?
options: Maximizing the total amount of profit for the owners of the company
Ensuring the fair and equitable distribution of economic goods and services
Following the specific religious traditions of the host country's people
Ignoring the impact of business decisions on the local environment

questions.text: The 'Schengen Agreement' allows for which of the following in Europe?
options: The use of a single currency in every country on the continent
The abolition of internal border checks between many European nations
The creation of a single European army that is led by one general
The requirement that everyone in Europe must speak at least two languages

questions.text: An 'anti-dumping' duty is a special tariff that is intended to:
options: Punish foreign firms that sell their products at unfairly low prices
Prevent companies from throwing away their trash in the local rivers
Help the government pay for the cost of cleaning up the environment
Increase the profit margins for companies that export luxury goods

questions.text: The term 'FDI' stands for which of the following in international business?
options: Foreign Direct Investment
Federal Department of Industry
Financial Data Integration
Foreign Delivery Insurance

questions.text: A 'horizontal' FDI occurs when a company invests in:
options: A foreign industry that provides raw materials for its domestic factory
The same industry abroad as the one in which it operates at home
A completely different industry than the one it currently operates in
A company that sells the finished products that it currently makes

questions.text: The 'Theocratic Law' system is based on which of the following?
options: A long history of court cases and the decisions made by various judges
Religious teachings and the interpretation of various sacred texts
A detailed set of written laws that are created by a central government
The personal whims and desires of a single person who is in power

questions.text: Hofstede's 'Long-Term Orientation' dimension measures a society's:
options: Preference for maintaining time-honored traditions and social norms
Focus on future rewards, perseverance, and the importance of thrift
Willingness to allow citizens to influence the government's decisions
Ability to build high-speed trains and other long-term infrastructures

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of 'product adaptation' for a foreign market?
options: Selling the exact same computer in Japan that is currently sold in the U.S.
Changing the flavor of a soft drink to match the local tastes in India
Using the same TV commercial in every country where the product is sold
Refusing to sell a product in a country that has a different language

questions.text: The 'Balance of Trade' is the difference between a country's total:
options: Income tax revenue and its total government spending for the year
Exports of goods and its total imports of goods during a period
Foreign investments and the total investments made by local citizens
Gold reserves and the total amount of paper money currently in use

questions.text: A 'pegged' exchange rate is one where the value of a currency is:
options: Determined entirely by the daily movements of the global oil market
Fixed relative to a reference currency like the U.S. Dollar or Euro
Changed every hour by a computer program that monitors the news
Allowed to fluctuate freely based on the supply and demand in the market

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of 'host-country' managers?
options: They are more likely to be loyal to the home office of the corporation
They have a better understanding of the local culture and language
They are much cheaper to hire than any of the people in the home country
They already know all the technical secrets of the parent company

questions.text: The 'Friedman Doctrine' suggests that the only social responsibility of business is to:
options: Protect the environment and provide high-quality healthcare for all
Increase profits for shareholders while staying within the rules of law
Provide free products and services to the poor in developing nations
Support the political party that is currently in power in the country

questions.text: The 'Trans-Pacific Partnership' (now CPTPP) is a trade agreement between:
options: Only the countries that are located on the continent of South America
Nations that border the Pacific Ocean, including Japan and Australia
The United States, Canada, and every country that is in the European Union
China, Russia, and the countries that are located in Northern Africa

questions.text: An 'administrative trade policy' is a bureaucratic rule that is designed to:
options: Make it easier for foreign companies to sell their products in the land
Make it difficult for foreign imports to enter a specific country
Provide free government consulting services to any international firm
Eliminate all the paperwork that is required to export goods abroad

questions.text: The 'Porter's Diamond' model identifies four attributes that promote:
options: The total amount of corruption in a country's government agencies
The competitive advantage of a nation in a particular industry
The rate of inflation in a country that uses a fixed exchange rate
The number of people who are willing to buy luxury goods from abroad

questions.text: A 'vertical' FDI occurs when a company invests in a foreign facility that:
options: Provides inputs for the firm's domestic production processes
Produces the exact same products that the firm makes in its home land
Sells the company's products to local citizens in the foreign market
Is located in a country that has no existing trade with the home nation

questions.text: Which of the following is true about 'Common Law' systems?
options: They are based on a very strict and detailed set of written codes
They rely on tradition, precedent, and the interpretation of judges
They are used primarily in countries that have a theocratic government
They prohibit any form of private ownership of business or property

questions.text: The term 'paralanguage' refers to the study of which of the following?
options: The literal translation of words from one language into another one
The non-verbal vocal cues such as pitch, volume, and rate of speech
The formal grammar and syntax rules of a foreign country's language
The use of written symbols like emojis to convey meaning in an email

questions.text: A 'global strategy' in marketing is most appropriate when there are:
options: High pressures for local responsiveness and low pressures for cost
High pressures for cost reduction and low pressures for local adaptation
No pressures for either cost reduction or local adaptation in the market
High levels of government intervention in every single global region

questions.text: The 'International Bank for Reconstruction and Development' is part of the:
options: International Monetary Fund
World Bank Group
World Trade Organization
United Nations

questions.text: A 'technical analysis' of currency exchange rates uses which of the following?
options: Economic variables like inflation rates and interest rate levels
Historical price data and various chart patterns to predict trends
The personal opinions of government officials and central bankers
The total amount of physical gold that is stored in a country's vaults

questions.text: Which of the following is a disadvantage of an 'ethnocentric' staffing policy?
options: It can lead to a lack of control over the foreign operations of the firm
It can result in cultural myopia and a failure to understand local needs
It is much cheaper than hiring people from the host country of the office
It makes it impossible to transfer any technical skills to the subsidiary

questions.text: The 'Global Compact' is a voluntary initiative for businesses launched by the:
options: World Trade Organization
United Nations
World Bank
International Monetary Fund

questions.text: Which of the following is a 'common market' in the South American region?
options: Mercosur
ASEAN
USMCA
COMESA

questions.text: A 'trade embargo' is a complete ban on trade with a:
options: Single company that has violated a national environmental regulation
Specific country or a group of countries for political or security reasons
Product category that is considered to be harmful to the local people
Foreign individual who has failed to pay their income taxes on time
